sen.j: 歌川 国芳（うたがわ くによし、1798年1月1日（寛政9年11月15日 (旧暦)） - 1861年4月14日（文久元年3月5日 (旧暦)〉）は、江戸時代末期の浮世絵。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi UTAGAWA (January 1, 1798 - April 14, 1861) was a Ukiyo-e artist who lived during the end of the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 和文：浮世絵→浮世絵師と理解して訳しています。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi UTAGAWA (January 1, 1798 - April 14, 1861) was an Ukiyo-e artist who lived during the end of the Edo Period.
Kuniyoshi UTAGAWA (January 1, 1798 - April 14, 1861) was an Ukiyo-e artist who lived during the end of the Edo Period.

sen.j: 号 (称号)は一勇斎。
sen.e: His second name or alias was Yusai.
His second name or alias was Yusai.
His second name or alias was Ichiyusai.
sen.cmt: Yusaiを Ichiyusaiに変更しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代末期を代表する浮世絵師の一人である。
sen.e: He was one of the leading Ukiyo-e artists during the end of the Edo Period.
He was one of the leading Ukiyo-e artists during the end of the Edo Period.
He was one of the leading Ukiyo-e artists during the end of the Edo Period.

sen.j: しかし国芳は、同時代に活動した葛飾北斎や歌川広重らの人気絵師に比べ、日本における知名度や評価は必ずしも高いとは言えなかった。
sen.e: However, unlike popular contemporaries among Ukiyo-e artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Hiroshige UTAGAWA, Kuniyoshi was not well known or highly appreciated in Japan.
However, unlike popular contemporaries among Ukiyo-e artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Hiroshige UTAGAWA, Kuniyoshi was not well known or highly appreciated in Japan.
However, unlike popular contemporaries among Ukiyo-e artists such as Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Hiroshige UTAGAWA, Kuniyoshi was not well known or highly appreciated in Japan.

sen.j: 「幕末の奇想の絵師」として注目され、再評価されるようになるのは20世紀後半になってからである。
sen.e: It was not until late 20th century that he started to be featured and re-evaluated as 'a unique painter in the Bakumatsu period (end of the Edo Period, last days of the Tokugawa shogunate)'.
It was not until late 20th century that he started to be featured and re-evaluated as 'a unique painter in the Bakumatsu period (end of the Edo Period, last days of the Tokugawa shogunate)'.
It was not until late 20th century that he started to be featured and re-evaluated as 'a unique painter in the Bakumatsu period (end of the Edo Period, last days of the Tokugawa shogunate)'.

sen.j: 2008年、富山県の農家の蔵から国芳を中心とした歌川派の版木が368枚発見され、購入した国立歴史民俗博物館により2009年に公開された。
sen.e: In 2008, 368 printing woodblocks of the UTAGAWA school including Kuniyoshi's were found in the storehouse of a farmer in Toyama Prefecture, and the National Museum of Japanese History which bought these woodblocks exhibited them to the public in 2009.

In 2008, 368 printing woodblocks of the UTAGAWA school including Kuniyoshi's were found in the storehouse of a farmer in Toyama Prefecture, and the National Museum of Japanese History which bought these woodblocks exhibited them to the public in 2009.

In 2008, 368 printing woodblocks of the UTAGAWA school including Kuniyoshi's were found in the storehouse of a farmer in Toyama Prefecture, and the National Museum of Japanese History which bought these woodblocks exhibited them to the public in 2009.

sen.j: これにより、国芳作品の創作過程の解明および浮世絵本来の色の復元が始まっている。
sen.e: This prompted the analysis of the creation process of Kuniyoshi's works and restoration of the colors which were faded away from Kuniyoshi's original Ukiyo-e prints.
This prompted the analysis of the creation process of Kuniyoshi's works and restoration of the colors which were faded away from Kuniyoshi's original Ukiyo-e prints.
This prompted the analysis of the creation process of Kuniyoshi's works and restoration of the colors which were faded away from Kuniyoshi's original Ukiyo-e prints.

sen.j: この版木については同年4月12日放送のBShi「ハイビジョン特集 幻の色 よみがえる浮世絵」、5月16日放送のNHK総合「ワンダー×ワンダー 浮世絵 よみがえる幻の色」で取り上げられた。
sen.e: The discovery of the printing woodblocks was featured on the TV programs under the title, 'hi-vision special: Maboroshi no Iro Yomigaeru Ukiyo-e (Reviving colors, Restoration of Ukiyo-e)' broadcast on April 12, 2009, and another TV program titled 'wonder x wonder Ukiyo-e Yomigaeru Maboroshi no Iro (Restoring faded colors)' on May 16, the same year.

The discovery of the printing woodblocks was featured on the TV programs under the title, 'hi-vision special: Maboroshi no Iro Yomigaeru Ukiyo-e (Reviving colors, Restoration of Ukiyo-e)' broadcast on April 12, 2009, and another TV program titled 'wonder x wonder Ukiyo-e Yomigaeru Maboroshi no Iro (Restoring faded colors)' on May 16, the same year.

The discovery of the printing woodblocks was featured on the TV programs under the title, 'hi-vision special: Maboroshi no Iro Yomigaeru Ukiyo-e (Reviving colors, Restoration of Ukiyo-e)' broadcast on April 12, 2009, and another TV program titled 'wonder x wonder Ukiyo-e Yomigaeru Maboroshi no Iro (Restoring faded colors)' on May 16, the same year.

sen.j: 国芳は、1797年（寛政9年）、江戸日本橋 (東京都中央区)に染物屋の息子として生まれた。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi was born in 1797 as a son of the owner of a somemono shop (a silk dyer) in Nihonbashi, Edo (Chuo Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).
Kuniyoshi was born in 1797 as a son of the owner of a somemono shop (a silk dyer) in Nihonbashi, Edo (Chuo Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).
Kuniyoshi was born in 1797 as a son of the owner of a somemono shop (a silk dyer) in Nihonbashi, Edo (Chuo Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 本名は井草芳三郎。
sen.e: His real name was 井草芳三郎.
sen.cmt: 井草芳三郎.：読み方不明です。
sen.e: His real name was 井草芳三郎.
His real name was 井草芳三郎.

sen.j: 風景版画で国際的に有名な歌川広重とは同年の生まれであり、同時代に活動した。
sen.e: Both Kuniyoshi and Hiroshige UTAGAWA who has enjoyed an international reputation for his landscape woodblock prints were born in the same year and were active as a painter during the same period.
Both Kuniyoshi and Hiroshige UTAGAWA, who has enjoyed an international reputation for his landscape woodblock prints, were born in the same year and were active as painters during the same period.
Both Kuniyoshi and Hiroshige UTAGAWA, who has enjoyed an international reputation for his landscape woodblock prints, were born in the same year and were active as painters during the same period.

sen.j: 1811年（文化8年）、15歳で初代歌川豊国（1769年 - 1825年）に入門。
sen.e: In 1811, Kuniyoshi became a disciple of Toyokuni UTAGAWA (1769 - 1825) at the age of 15.
In 1811, Kuniyoshi became a disciple of Toyokuni UTAGAWA (1769 - 1825) at the age of 15.
In 1811, Kuniyoshi became a disciple of Toyokuni UTAGAWA (1769 - 1825) at the age of 15.

sen.j: 豊国は華麗な役者絵で一世を風靡した花形絵師であり、弟子に歌川国貞（1786年 - 1864年）がいる。
sen.e: Toyokuni was a star painter who swept the Ukiyo-e art world with his gorgeous Ukiyo-e prints of Kabuki actors, and his disciples included Kunisada UTAGAWA (1786 - 1864).
Toyokuni was a star painter who swept the Ukiyo-e art world with his gorgeous Ukiyo-e prints of Kabuki actors, and his disciples included Kunisada UTAGAWA (1786 - 1864).
Toyokuni was a star painter who swept the Ukiyo-e art world with his gorgeous Ukiyo-e prints of Kabuki actors, and his disciples included Kunisada UTAGAWA (1786 - 1864).

sen.j: 国芳は入門の数年後、1814年（文化11年）頃から作品発表を開始している。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi started releasing his works around 1814, a few years after he became a pupil of Toyokuni.
Kuniyoshi started releasing his works around 1814, a few years after he became a pupil of Toyokuni.
Kuniyoshi started releasing his works around 1814, a few years after he became a pupil of Toyokuni.

sen.j: すでに歌川派を代表していた兄弟子、国直の支えもあって腕を磨く。
sen.e: His older disciple, Kunisada, who was already a leading painter of the UTAGAWA school, supported Kuniyoshi to improve his skills.
His older disciple, Kunisada, who was already a leading painter of the UTAGAWA school, supported Kuniyoshi to improve his skills.
His older disciple, Kunisada, who was already a leading painter of the UTAGAWA school, supported Kuniyoshi to improve his skills.

sen.j: 師・豊国没後の1827年（文政10年）頃に発表した『水滸伝』のシリーズが評判となる。
sen.e: One of his Mush-e (Ukiyo-e prints of warriors) series, "Suicide (The Water Margin)", was released around 1827 after his master Toyokuni died, and the work was well received among people.
One of his Mush-e (Ukiyo-e prints of warriors) series, "Suicide (The Water Margin)", was released around 1827 after his master Toyokuni died, and the work was well received among people.
One of his Musha-e (Ukiyo-e prints of warriors) series, "Suikoden" (The Water Margin), was released around 1827 after his master Toyokuni died, and the work was well received among people.
sen.cmt: Mush-eをMusha-eに変更しました。SuicideをSuikodenに変更しました。()を" "の外に移動させました。

sen.j: "武者絵の国芳"と称され、人気絵師の仲間入りをした。
sen.e: He was nicknamed "Kuniyoshi of Musha-e" and joined popular painters.
He was nicknamed "Kuniyoshi of Musha-e" and joined popular painters.
He was nicknamed "Kuniyoshi of Musha-e" and joined popular painters.

sen.j: 国芳には多くの門弟がおり、｢最後の浮世絵師｣と呼ばれた月岡芳年や、幕末から明治前期に活躍した異色の画家・河鍋暁斎も国芳に弟子入りしたことがあった。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi had many disciples, including Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA who was called 'The last Ukiyo-e painter', and Kyosai KAWANABE, a unique painter who was active from the end of Edo Period through to the early Meiji Period.

Kuniyoshi had many disciples, including Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA who was called 'The last Ukiyo-e painter', and Kyosai KAWANABE, a unique painter who was active from the end of Edo Period through to the early Meiji Period.

Kuniyoshi had many disciples, including Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA who was called 'The last Ukiyo-e painter', and Kyosai KAWANABE, a unique painter who was active from the end of Edo Period through to the early Meiji Period.

sen.j: 国芳は明治維新を目前にした1861年（文久元年）、数え年65歳で没している。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi died at the age of 65 (the age counted based on the traditional Japanese system) in 1861, just before the Maiji Restoration.
Kuniyoshi died at the age of 65 (the age counted based on the traditional Japanese system) in 1861, just before the Meiji Restoration.
Kuniyoshi died at the age of 65 (the age counted based on the traditional Japanese system) in 1861, just before the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 作品は役者絵、武者絵、美人画、名所絵（風景画）から戯画、春画までさまざまなジャンルにわたっているが、中でも歴史・伝説・物語などに題材を採り、大判3枚つづりの大画面に巨大なクジラや骸骨、化け物などが跳梁するダイナミックな作品に本領を発揮している。
sen.e: His works cover various genres from prints of Kabuki actors (Yakusha-e), of warriors (Musha-e), beautiful women (Bijin-ga) and landscapes (Fukei-ga), to caricature and erotic arts (Shun-ga), but especially, his skills are most reflected on dynamic large-sized pieces which depict histories, legends and stories through powerful subjects, such as massive whales, skeletons and monsters.

His works cover various genres from prints of Kabuki actors (Yakusha-e), of warriors (Musha-e), beautiful women (Bijin-ga) and landscapes (Fukei-ga), to caricature and erotic arts (Shun-ga), but especially, his skills are most reflected on dynamic large-sized pieces which depict histories, legends and stories through powerful subjects, such as massive whales, skeletons and monsters.

His works cover various genres from prints of Kabuki actors (Yakusha-e), warriors (Musha-e), beautiful women (Bijin-ga) and landscapes (Fukei-ga), to caricature and erotic arts (Shun-ga), but especially, his skills are most reflected on three dynamic large-sized pieces which depict histories, legends and stories through powerful subjects, such as massive whales, skeletons and monsters.
sen.cmt: warriorsの前のofを除去しました。dynamicの前にthreeを補いました。

sen.j: また、無類の猫好きとしても知られ、常に数匹の猫を飼い、懐に猫を抱いて作画していたと伝えられるほどで、猫を擬人化した作品も多い。
sen.e: Also known as an incomparable cat lover, Kuniyoshi kept several cats all the time, and it is even said that he painted with his cats in his arm and there are a plenty of his works in which cats are personified.

Also known as an incomparable cat lover, Kuniyoshi kept several cats all the time, and it is even said that he painted with his cats in his arm and there are a plenty of his works in which cats are personified.

Also known as an incomparable cat lover, Kuniyoshi kept several cats all the time, and it is even said that he painted with his cats in his arm and there are a plenty of his works in which cats are personified.

sen.j: 猫に限らず、狸・雀・蛸などの身近な動物を擬人化して世相を風刺したり、動物に託して江戸の庶民の生活を描写した作品も多い。
sen.e: Not only cats but also many other animals around him such as raccoons, sparrows and octopuses were also personified to satirize the world or to depict the everyday life of ordinary people in Edo (Tokyo).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Not only cats but also many other animals around him such as raccoons, sparrows and octopuses were also personified to satirize the world or to depict the everyday life of ordinary people in Edo (Tokyo).

Not only cats but also many other animals around him such as raccoons, sparrows and octopuses were also personified to satirize the world or to depict the everyday life of ordinary people in Edo (Tokyo).

sen.j: これらからは現代日本にてますます盛んな漫画・劇画の源流の一つを見る事ができよう。
sen.e: These works show one of the origins of the increasingly popular Manga (cartoons) and Gekiga (graphic novels) in modern Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These works show one of the origins of the increasingly popular Manga (cartoons) and Gekiga (graphic novels) in modern Japan.
These works show one of the origins of the increasingly popular Manga (cartoons) and Gekiga (graphic novels) in modern Japan.

sen.j: 「寄せ絵」や、自宅で絵を描く自身の顔の前を、絵の中の動物や人物が横切り、自身の顔を隠している｢自画像｣のような遊び心のある作品も国芳の得意としたものである。
sen.e: Types of pictures that Kuniyoshi were good at include 'Yose-e' (literally, an assembled picture) and 'Jigazo' (a self-portrait) and they contain lots of his playful spirits; one of his self-portraits shows that he is drawing himself but his face is nonidentifiable because an animal or a human is cutting across in front of him.
sen.cmt: 「寄せ絵」：文字どおりに訳しています。
sen.e: Types of pictures that Kuniyoshi were good at include 'Yose-e' (literally, an assembled picture) and 'Jigazo' (a self-portrait) and they contain lots of his playful spirits; one of his self-portraits shows that he is drawing himself but his face is unidentifiable because an animal or a human is cutting across in front of him.

Types of pictures that Kuniyoshi were good at include 'Yose-e' (literally, an assembled picture) and 'Jigazo' (a self-portrait) and they contain lots of his playful spirits; one of his self-portraits shows that he is drawing himself but his face is unidentifiable because an animal or a human is cutting across in front of him.

sen.j: 華美をいましめる天保の改革（1841年 -）以後、幕府の禁令によって役者や遊女の1枚刷り錦絵は出版できなくなってしまう。
sen.e: After the Tenpo Reforms (1841 -) which prevented people from enjoying luxury items, Bakufu (Japanese feudal government) banned a stand-alone full color Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) featuring Kabuki actors or Yujo (prostitute).

After the Tenpo Reforms (1841 -) which prevented people from enjoying luxury items, Bakufu (Japanese feudal government) banned a stand-alone full color Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) featuring Kabuki actors or Yujo (prostitute).

After the Tenpo Reforms (1841 -) which prevented people from enjoying luxury items, Bakufu (Japanese feudal government) banned a stand-alone full color Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) featuring Kabuki actors or Yujo (prostitute).

sen.j: しかし、国芳は、そんななかでも、いやそんななかであるからこそ持ち前の江戸っ子気質を大いに発揮している。
sen.e: However, amid such difficulties, Kuniyoshi kept his spirit high and exerted his own Edokko nature (a typical personality of someone living in the Edo area) to overcome challenges facing him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, amid such difficulties, Kuniyoshi kept his spirits high and exerted his own Edokko nature (a typical personality of someone living in the Edo area) to overcome challenges facing him.
However, amid such difficulties, Kuniyoshi kept his spirits high and exerted his own Edokko nature (a typical personality of someone living in the Edo area) to overcome challenges facing him.

sen.j: 魚の顔を役者の似顔にするなど、さまざまな便法で禁令を潜り抜け、絵師は役者の似顔を世に送り出し続けた。
sen.e: He used various methods to slip through the ban to release portraits of Kabuki actors; for example, one of his Ukiyo-e portrays a fish which holds a face of a Kabuki actor.
He used various methods to slip through the ban to release portraits of Kabuki actors; for example, one of his Ukiyo-e portrays a fish with the face of a Kabuki actor.
He used various methods to slip through the ban to release portraits of Kabuki actors; for example, one of his Ukiyo-e portrays a fish with the face of a Kabuki actor.

sen.j: 国芳はまた、柴田是真（蒔絵、画家）、渡辺崋山（田原藩家老、学者、画家）ら当時の文化人とも交流があり、画風にも当時の新知識を彼なりに研究・吸収した跡が見られる。
sen.e: Kuniyoshi also built a good relationship with various cultural figures, including Zeshin SHIBATA (a maki-e painter [Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder] and a traditional painter) and Kazan WATANABE (the chief retainer of the TAHARA clan, a scholar and a painter), and his paintings show that he acquired new knowledge from them and used it in his own way.

Kuniyoshi also built a good relationship with various cultural figures, including Zeshin SHIBATA (a maki-e painter [Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder] and a traditional painter) and Kazan WATANABE (the chief retainer of the TAHARA clan, a scholar and a painter), and his paintings show that he acquired new knowledge from them and used it in his own way.

Kuniyoshi also built a good relationship with various cultural figures, including Zeshin SHIBATA (a maki-e painter [Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder] and a traditional painter) and Kazan WATANABE (the chief retainer of the TAHARA clan, a scholar and a painter), and his paintings show that he acquired new knowledge from them and used it in his own way.

sen.j: 『相馬の古内裏』という作品に登場する巨大な骸骨（「国芳画廊」の項を参照）は西洋の解剖学の書物を研究した成果だと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that the massive skeleton drawn in "Soma no Furudairi " (for details, refer to the following 'Kuniyoshi Gallery' section), represents the knowledge he acquired through books on western anatomy.

It is said that the massive skeleton drawn in "Soma no Furudairi " (for details, refer to the following 'Kuniyoshi Gallery' section), represents the knowledge he acquired through books on western anatomy.

It is said that the massive skeleton drawn in "Soma no Furudairi " (for details, refer to the following 'Kuniyoshi Gallery' section), represents the knowledge he acquired through books on western anatomy.

sen.j: また、『忠臣蔵十一段目夜討之図』は未熟ながらも西洋画の遠近法さまざまな図法（遠近法の一種）を学んだ跡が見え、画面に奥行きと緊張感を与えている。
sen.e: Also, perspective which Kuniyoshi learned from Western painting is used in his another piece, "Chushingura Juichi-danme Youchi no Zu"; although he used perspective immaturely in this work, he succeeded in giving a depth and a sense of tension to the piece.

Also, perspective which Kuniyoshi learned from Western painting is used in his another piece, "Chushingura Juichi-danme Youchi no Zu"; although he used perspective immaturely in this work, he succeeded in giving a depth and a sense of tension to the piece.

Also, perspective which Kuniyoshi learned from Western painting is used in his another piece, "Chushingura Juichi-danme Youchi no Zu"; although he used perspective immaturely in this work, he succeeded in giving a depth and a sense of tension to the piece.

sen.j: 『太平記兵庫合戦』 ：福海寺で足利尊氏を探す、白藤彦七郎。
sen.e: "Taiheki Hyogo Gassen"(The Record of the Great Peace; Battle in Hyogo): Hikoshichiro SHIRAFUJI looking for Takauji ASHIKAGA in Fukukai-ji Temple.

sen.e: Picture-1 "Soma no Furudairi ": OYA no Taro Mitsukuni fighting against the specter, Soma no Furudairi, which is maneuvered by Princess Takiyasha-hime.

sen.j: これらは縦3枚を合わせて一組とした国芳得意の大判作品。
sen.e: This is the Kuniyoshi's specialty, a large-sized Ukiyo-e triptychs, consisting of three pieces.
sen.cmt: 「これら」が何を指しているのかわかりませんので、訳出でも曖昧になっています。http://www.kuniyoshiproject.com/Genji%20triptychs.htm

sen.e: Picture-2 "Uji-gawa River no Tatakai no Zu"(The battle of vanguard at Uji-gawa River): Kagesue KAJIWARA is drawn on the left and Takatsuna SASAKI in the center.

sen.j: 画像-4：『大山石尊良辧瀧之図』 大山石尊（石尊大権現、現・大山阿夫利神社）の滝に参拝する人々。
sen.e: Picture-4 "Oyama Sekison Ryoben no Taki": people paying a visit to the fall of Oyama Sekison (Sekison daigongen [Great Avatar]. Current Oyama Afuri-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 画像-5：『牛若丸僧正坊隋武術覚図』 鞍馬山にて大天狗の鞍馬山僧正坊（中央）から武術の手解きを受ける源義経（牛若丸。右上）。
sen.e: Picture-5 "Ushiwaka-maru Sojobo Zuibujutu Oboe no Zu": Sojobo of Mt. Kurama, a Dai-Tengu (a long-nosed great goblin) (in the center), teaching MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune (Ushiwaka-maru, on the right) martial arts at Mt. Kurama.
sen.cmt: 牛若丸僧正坊隋武術覚図：読み方不明です。
sen.e: Picture-5 "Ushiwaka-maru Sojobo Zuibujutu Oboe no Zu": Sojobo of Mt. Kurama, a Dai-Tengu (a long-nosed great goblin) (in the center), teaching MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune (Ushiwaka-maru, on the right) martial arts at Mt. Kurama.

Picture-5 "Ushiwaka-maru Sojobo Zuibujutsu Oboe no Zu": Sojobo of Mt. Kurama, a Dai-Tengu (a long-nosed great goblin) (in the center), teaching MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune (Ushiwaka-maru, on the right) martial arts at Mt. Kurama.
sen.cmt: Zuibujutuを Zuibujutsuに変更しました。読みは不明のままです。

sen.j: 画像-6：『義経一代記 五条ノ橋之図』 牛若丸と武蔵坊弁慶、五条大橋の闘い。
sen.e: Picture-6 "Yoshitsune Ichidai-Ki Gojo no Hashi no Zu": a fight between Ushiwaka-maru and Musashibo Benkei on the Gojo-ohashi Bridge.

sen.j: 画像-7：大物浦にて義経主従と戦う平知盛の霊の海中の陣。
sen.e: Picture-7: A battle under water between the ghost of TAIRA no Tomonori and Yoshitsune and his retainers in Daimotsu no Ura.
Picture-7: A battle under water between the ghost of TAIRA no Tomonori and Yoshitsune and his retainers in Daimotsu no Ura.

sen.e: Picture-9: "Shichifukujin" (Seven Deities of Good Luck)
Picture-9: "Shichifukujin" (Seven Deities of Good Luck)
Picture-9: "Shichifukujin" (Seven Deities of Good Luck)

sen.j: 画像-10：『其のまま地口 猫飼好五十三疋』（そのまま-じぐち・みやうかいこう-ごじうさんびき） 東海道五十三次の宿場町名を地口で猫の仕草として描いたもの。
sen.e: Picture-10 "Sonomama Jiguchi Miyaukaikou Gojusan-biki"(Cats suggested as The Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido): a picture on which the names of inn towns from 'Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi' are transformed into cats' behavior.

Picture-10 "Sonomama Jiguchi Miyaukaikou Gojusan-biki" (Cats suggested as The Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido): a picture on which the names of inn towns from 'Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi' are transformed into cats' behavior.

Picture-10 "Sonomama Jiguchi Miyaukaikou Gojusan-biki" (Cats suggested as The Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido): a picture on which the names of inn towns from 'Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi' are transformed into cats' behavior.

sen.j: 江戸の日本橋 (東京都中央区)日本橋（橋梁）は「二本ぶし（2本の鰹節）」、大磯宿は「（獲物が）重いぞ」、見附宿は「寝つき」、御油宿は「恋」、桑名宿は「食わぬ」、石薬師宿は「いちゃつき」、土山宿は「ぶち邪魔」、草津宿は「炬燵」、そして、捕まった鼠の悲鳴「ぎやう」を京に掛けて締めとしている。
sen.e: In this play-on-word picture, Nihonbashi Bridge (chuo Ward, Tokyo) is changed into 'Nihon bushi' (two dried bonitos), Oiso-juku into 'Omoi zo' ([a prey is] too heavy), Mistuke-juku into 'Netsuki' (to fall asleep), Goyu-shuku into 'Koi' (romance), Kuwana-juku into 'Kuwanu' (not to eat), Ishiyakushi-juku into 'Ichatsuki' (to flirt), Tsuchiyama-juku into 'Buchi Jama' (very bothersome), Kusatsu-juku into 'Kotatsu' (table with heater) and a squeak of a mouse Gyau is changed into Kyo (Kyoto).

In this play-on-word picture, Nihonbashi Bridge (chuo Ward, Tokyo) is changed into 'Nihon bushi' (two dried bonitos), Oiso-juku into 'Omoi zo' (it's too heavy), Mistuke-juku into 'Netsuki' (to fall asleep), Goyu-shuku into 'Koi' (romance), Kuwana-juku into 'Kuwanu' (not to eat), Ishiyakushi-juku into 'Ichatsuki' (to flirt), Tsuchiyama-juku into 'Buchi Jama' (very bothersome), Kusatsu-juku into 'Kotatsu' (table with heater) and a squeak of a mouse Gyau is changed into Kyo (Kyoto).

In this play-on-word picture, Nihonbashi Bridge (chuo Ward, Tokyo) is changed into 'Nihon bushi' (two dried bonitos), Oiso-juku into 'Omoi zo' (it's too heavy), Mistuke-juku into 'Netsuki' (to fall asleep), Goyu-shuku into 'Koi' (romance), Kuwana-juku into 'Kuwanu' (not to eat), Ishiyakushi-juku into 'Ichatsuki' (to flirt), Tsuchiyama-juku into 'Buchi Jama' (very bothersome), Kusatsu-juku into 'Kotatsu' (table with heater) and a squeak of a mouse Gyau is changed into Kyo (Kyoto).

sen.j: 画像-11：『山城国 井手の玉川』 美人画。

Picture-11 "Yamashiro no kuni Ide no Tamagawa": Bijinga (a type of ukiyo-e portraying beautiful women)

sen.j: 画像-13：『みかけハこハゐが とんだいゝ人だ』 「大ぜいの人が よつて たかつて とふと いゝ人をこしらへた とかく人のことハ 人にしてもらハねバ いゝ人にはならぬ（大勢の人が寄ってたかって、とうとう、いい人をこしらえた。
sen.e: Picture-13 "Mikake ha Kowai ga Tonda Ii Hito Da": Many people are assembled to create one good person.
sen.cmt: （大勢の人が寄ってたかって、とうとう、いい人をこしらえた。兎角、人の事は人にしてもらわねば、いい人には成らぬ）：定訳不明です。
sen.e: Picture-13 "Mikake ha Kowai ga Tonda Ii Hito Da": Many people are assembled to create one good person.
Picture-13 "Mikake ha Kowai ga Tonda Ii Hito Da": Many people are assembled to create one good person.

sen.j: 兎角、人の事は人にしてもらわねば、いい人には成らぬ）」 寄せ絵。
sen.e: It is impossible for any other creatures to create a good human.
sen.cmt: （大勢の人が寄ってたかって、とうとう、いい人をこしらえた。兎角、人の事は人にしてもらわねば、いい人には成らぬ）：定訳不明です。
sen.e: It is impossible for any other creatures to create a good human.
It is impossible for any other creatures to create a good human.
